Internet search found graduation programs in Multiple (Ethiopia, Ghana, Honduras, India, Pakistan, Peru): Perplexity search result: Multiple authoritative sources confirm that the Graduation program, also known as the Ultra Poor Graduation Approach, was rigorously evaluated and piloted in Ethiopia, Ghana, Honduras, India, Pakistan, and Peru, among other countries[1][3][4][5][6]. It is explicitly described as a graduation (or multifaceted) poverty alleviation program, integrating several components: regular cash or consumption support (cash transfers or food stipends), productive asset transfers (e.g., livestock, inventory), skills training, savings facilitation, and intensive coaching[4][5][6][7]. Impact evaluations and program documents consistently list both cash/consumption support and productive asset transfers as core features present in all country pilots, confirming the Cash and Asset elements[4][6][7].
